text: Moab rebelled against Israel after Ahab died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Ahaziah had fallen through the lattice in his upper room in Samaria and lay injured. He sent messengers to Ekron with these orders: “Go and consult with Ekron’s god Baal-zebub to find out if I’m going to recover from this injury.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the angel of the Lord spoke to Elijah the foreigner, “Get up and go meet the messengers from the king of Samaria. Ask them ‘Is it because there is no God in Israel that you’re going to consult with Ekron’s god Baal-zebub?
speaker: Narrator

text: Now therefore this is what the Lord says: “You won’t be getting up from that bed of yours on which you’re lying. You will most certainly die!”’” So Elijah got up and went.
speaker: Narrator

text: The messengers returned to the king and he asked them, “What’s this? You’ve come back?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They replied, “We met a man who told us, ‘Go back to the king who sent you and ask him, “Is it because there is no God in Israel that you’re going to consult with Baal-zebub, the god of Ekron? Therefore you won’t be getting up from that bed on which you’re lying. You will most certainly die!”’”
speaker: Narrator

text: He told them, “Describe the man who met you and told you these things.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
They answered, “The man was a hairy fellow. He wore a leather sash around his waist.”
The king responded, “It’s Elijah, that foreigner!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king sent out 50 men, along with their leader. The leader approached Elijah, who was sitting at the top of a hill. He ordered Elijah, “Hey, man of God! The king orders you to come down!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah responded to the leader who was in charge of the 50 soldiers, “So I’m a man of God, am I? If so, may fire fall from heaven and devour you and your 50 soldiers…” Just then, fire fell from heaven and devoured that leader and his 50 soldiers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later the king tried again—he sent another company of 50 soldiers, along with their leader, who ordered Elijah, “Hey, man of God! This is what the king orders: ‘Come down!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah responded to the leader and to his entire company, “So I’m a man of God, am I? If so, may fire fall from heaven and devour you and your 50 soldiers…” Just then, fire fell from heaven and devoured him and his 50 soldiers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king tried yet again! The king sent a third company of 50 soldiers along with their leader. The third leader went up the hill, approached Elijah, fell on his knees in front of him, and begged him, “Hey, man of God, please treat my life and the lives of these servants of yours as precious!
speaker: Narrator

text: Look how fire fell from heaven and devoured the two other companies of 50 soldiers, along with their captains, but now please treat me as if my life were precious!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord told Elijah, “Go down the hill with that man. Don’t be afraid of him!” So Elijah got up and went down with him to meet the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elijah spoke to the king, “This is what the Lord says: ‘Since you sent messengers to consult with Baal-zebub, the god of Ekron—is it because there is no God in Israel with whom to consult regarding his word?—therefore you’re not getting up from the bed on which you’re lying. You certainly will die!’”
speaker: Narrator

text:
And die he did, just as the Lord had said and just as Elijah had spoken!
After this, Jehoram ascended to the throne during the second year of the reign of Jehoshaphat’s son Jehoram from Judah. He took the place of Ahaziah, who had no son.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of Ahaziah’s activities are recorded in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel, are they not?
speaker: Narrator

text: As the time drew near when the Lord was about to take Elijah to heaven in a wind storm, Elijah and Elisha were on their way from Gilgal.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Elijah instructed Elisha, “Remain here on this side, please, because the Lord is sending me as far as Bethel.”
But Elisha replied, “As the Lord lives, I’m not going to leave you while you’re still alive!” So they both went on to Bethel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the Guild of Prophets who lived in Bethel came out to greet Elisha, they asked him, “You are aware, aren’t you, that later today the Lord is going to remove your master from being your mentor?”
“Of course I’m aware of it,” he said. “Calm down.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Elijah also spoke to him, “Elisha, remain here on this side, please, because the Lord is sending me to Jericho.”
But Elisha responded, “As the Lord lives, and while you’re still alive, I’m not going to leave you!” So they went to Jericho.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Guild of Prophets who lived in Jericho approached Elisha and asked him, “You are aware, aren’t you, that later today the Lord is going to remove your master from being your mentor?”
“Of course I’m aware of it,” he said. “Calm down.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Elijah also spoke to him, “Elisha, remain here on this side, please, because the Lord is sending me to the Jordan River.”
But Elisha responded, “As the Lord lives, and while you’re still alive, I’m not going to leave you!” So they went on their way,
speaker: Narrator

text: accompanied by 50 men from the Guild of Prophets, who stood at a short distance from them while they were both standing by the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah took off his ornamented cloak, wrapped it up in a roll, struck the water, and all of a sudden the water divided into two parts! One side of the river stood still opposite the other until the two of them crossed over on dry ground.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When they had crossed the Jordan River, Elijah invited Elisha, “Ask me what you want me to do for you before I’m taken away from you.”
So Elisha asked, “Please, may there be a double portion of your spirit upon me!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “That’s a hard thing to ask for,” Elijah answered, “but if you see me while I’m being taken from you, it will happen for you. But if you don’t see me, it won’t happen.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As they continued on, talking as they went, suddenly chariots blazing with fire and pulled by fiery horses appeared, separated the two of them, and Elijah ascended in a wind storm to heaven!
speaker: Narrator

text:
As Elisha continued to watch, he cried out, “My father! My father! The chariots of Israel and its cavalry!” Then he did not see Elijah anymore.
After this, Elisha gripped his clothes that he was wearing, tore them apart into two pieces,
speaker: Narrator

text: picked up Elijah’s ornamented cloak that had fallen from him, and went back to stand on the bank of the Jordan River.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha took hold of Elijah’s ornamental cloak that had been left behind, struck the water, and cried out: “Where is the Lord God of Elijah?” All of a sudden, after he had struck the water, the water divided into two parts! One side of the river stood opposite the other, and Elisha crossed over.
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as the Guild of Prophets who lived adjacent to Jericho saw Elisha, they began to announce, “The spirit of Elijah is at rest on Elisha!” So they came out to meet him and they greeted him by bowing low to the ground in front of him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then they asked Elisha, “Look! We have 50 valiant men here with your servant! Please let them go out and search for your master Elijah. Perhaps the Spirit of the Lord has taken him up on a mountain or into a valley.”
Elisha responded, “Don’t bother searching.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they persisted until he was frustrated, so he said, “Send them out!” So they sent out the 50 men, and they looked around for three days but did not find Elijah.
speaker: Narrator

text: By the time they returned, Elisha was living in Jericho. Then Elisha asked them, “Didn’t I tell you not to go?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The men who lived in the city addressed Elisha. “Look now,” they said, “our city’s location is good, as you have been observing, but the water springs here are bad and the land isn’t sustaining crops.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha ordered them, “Bring me a new bowl and put some salt in it.” So they brought him what he had requested.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha went out to the springs, threw the salt into them, and declared, “This is what the Lord says: ‘I have purified these waters. Neither death nor barrenness is to flow from them anymore.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: As a result, the water springs remain pure to this day, just as Elisha had declared.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, Elisha left there to go up to Bethel, and as he was traveling along the road, some insignificant young men came from the city and started mocking him. They told him, “Get on up, baldy! Get on up, baldy!”
speaker: Narrator

text: He looked behind him, took note of the young men, and cursed them in the name of the Lord. Suddenly two female bears emerged from the woods and mauled 42 of the young men.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, he left from there to go to Mt. Carmel, and from there he went back to Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahab’s son Jehoram ascended to the throne of Israel at Samaria during the eighteenth year of the reign of Judah’s King Jehoshaphat. He reigned for twelve years,
speaker: Narrator

text: practicing evil in the Lord’s presence, only not to the extent that his mother and father had done—he forced abolition of the sacred pillar to Baal that his father had crafted.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even so, he kept on committing the sins that Nebat’s son Jeroboam had done, which ensnared Israel in sin—he never abandoned them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Moab’s King Mesha was a sheep breeder. He used to pay 100,000 lambs and the wool from 100,000 rams to the king of Israel as tribute.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Ahab died, the king of Moab rebelled against the king of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: So King Jehoram left Samaria at that time and mustered the entire army of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As he was going out, he sent this message to King Jehoshaphat of Judah: “The king of Moab has rebelled against me. Will you go with me to fight Moab?”
“I’m coming,” Jehoshaphat replied. “I’m like you! My army will act like your army and my cavalry like your cavalry,” Then Jehoshaphat added:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“What road do we take?”
Jehoram answered, “We’ll go along the Edom desert road.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king of Israel, the king of Judah, and the king of Edom made a complete circuit on the road for seven days, but there was no water for the army or for the livestock that accompanied them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king of Israel remarked, “Oh no! The Lord has summoned us three kings so he can hand us over to Moab, hasn’t he?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jehoshaphat asked, “Isn’t there a prophet who belongs to the Lord and through whom we can ask the Lord a question?”
One of the king of Israel’s attendants replied, “Shaphat’s son Elisha lives here. He used to be Elijah’s personal attendant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoshaphat answered, “He receives messages from the Lord.” So the king of Israel, Jehoshaphat, and the king of Edom went to visit Elisha.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Elisha asked the king of Israel, “What do I have in common with you? Go visit your parents’ prophets.”
The king of Israel replied, “No! The Lord has summoned these three kings so he can hand them over to Moab!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Elisha responded, “As the Lord of the Heavenly Armies lives, in whose presence I stand, I would never pay attention to you or even look in your direction were it not for my continuous respect for the presence of King Jehoshaphat of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now bring me a musician.”
As the musician played, the hand of the Lord rested on Elisha,
speaker: Narrator

text: so he said, “This is what the Lord says: ‘Fill this valley with trench after trench!’
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord says: ‘Though you won’t see wind or storm, nevertheless that river will overflow with water so that you, your cattle, and your livestock may drink.’
speaker: Narrator

text: And this is the easy part for the Lord—he’s also going to hand the Moabites over to you!
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you are to attack every fortified city and every significant city. Cut down every significant tree, fill in all of the water springs, and ruin every prime piece of land with stones.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The very next day, about the time of the morning offering, water suddenly appeared, coming from the direction of Edom, and the land overflowed with water!
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, all the Moabites heard that the kings had come up to attack them, so everyone old enough to wear battle armor was mustered to stand guard at the border.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the Moabites arose early that morning, the sun cast its rays on the water, and to the Moabites, the water across from them appeared to be red like blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they concluded, “This must be blood! The kings must have had one mighty big fight and each man killed the other! So let’s go get the battle spoil, Moab!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But when the Moabites arrived at the Israeli encampment, the Israelis got up and attacked them. The Moabites ran away from the Israelis, who followed them into the land as they continued their pursuit against Moab.
speaker: Narrator

text: They destroyed their cities, and all of them threw stones onto every piece of farm land, ruining the fields. Then they filled in all the water wells and chopped down all of the useful trees. Stone walls remained surrounding Kir-hareseth only, until the archers surrounded and attacked that city.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the king of Moab realized that the battle was going strongly against him, he took 700 expert swordsmen to attempt to break through to the king of Edom, but was unable to do so.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he took his firstborn son, whom he intended to reign after him, and offered him up as a burnt offering on the wall. There subsequently came great anger against Israel, so they abandoned the attack and returned to their homeland.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there happened to be a certain woman who had been the wife of a member of the Guild of Prophets. She cried out to Elisha, “My husband who served you has died, and you know that your servant feared the Lord. But a creditor has come to take away my children into indentured servitude!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Elisha responded, “What shall I do for you? Tell me what you have in your house.”
She replied, “Your servant has nothing in the entire house except for a flask of oil.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He told her, “Go out to all of your neighbors in the surrounding streets and borrow lots of pots from them. Don’t get just a few empty vessels, either.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then go in and shut the door behind you, taking only your children, and pour oil into all of the pots. As each one is filled, set it aside.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So she left Elisha, shut the door behind her and her children, and while they kept on bringing vessels to her, she kept on pouring oil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the last of the vessels had been filled, she told her son, “Bring me another pot!”
But he replied, “There isn’t even one pot left.” Then the oil stopped flowing.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, she went and told the man of God what had happened. So he said, “Go sell the oil, pay your debt, and you and your children will be able to live on the proceeds.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Some time later, Elisha went to Shunem, where he met a prominent and wealthy woman who persuaded him to have a meal with her. As a result, whenever he was in the area, he stopped by to eat with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: So she had a talk with her husband. “Look here! I’ve learned that this is a holy and godly man who comes by here on a regular basis.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now then, let’s build a small upper room and put a bed in it for him there, along with a table, a chair, and a lamp stand. That way, when he comes to visit, he can rest there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: One day, Elisha came by to visit and stopped in to rest in the upper chamber.
speaker: Narrator

text: He told his attendant Gehazi, “Call this Shunammite.” So when he had summoned her, she stood in front of him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Elisha told him, “Ask her, ‘Look how you’ve gone to all this trouble to care for us! What can I do for you? Do you wish to be mentioned to the king or to the head of the army?’”
She replied, “I’m at home living among my own people.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He responded, “What, then, is to be done on her behalf?”
Gehazi answered, “Well, she has no son and her husband is growing old.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Call her,” Elisha ordered. After he called her, she came and stood in the doorway,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and he told her, “About this time next year you will be embracing a son.”
“No, sir! Please, as a godly man, don’t mislead your servant!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the woman did conceive and did bear a son at that very same time the next year, just as Elisha had told her.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the child had grown up a bit, one day he went out to visit his father, who was with the harvesters.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He told his father, “My head! My head!”
So his father ordered his servant, “Carry him over to his mother!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the servant carried him over to his mother, where he rested on her lap until mid-day, and then he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: The woman went upstairs, laid him on the bed belonging to the man of God, and shut the door, leaving him behind as she left.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she called to her husband and asked him, “Please send me one of the servants, along with one of the donkeys, so I can ride quickly to see that godly man. I’ll be right back.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He asked her, “What’s the point of visiting him today? It’s not a New Moon, and it isn’t the Sabbath!”
But she kept saying, “Things will go well.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So she saddled a donkey and told her servant, “Forward, driver! Don’t slow down on my account, unless I tell you!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So out she went and eventually she arrived at Mount Carmel to visit the man of God.
When the man of God noticed her from a distance, he told his attendant Gehazi, “Look! There’s the woman from Shunem!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Please run out quickly and greet her. Ask her, ‘Are things going well with you? Are things going well with your husband? Are things going well with your child?’”
She answered Gehazi, “Things are going well.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As she came near the man of God on the mountain, she grabbed his feet. When Gehazi intervened to push her away, the man of God said, “Leave her alone! She is deeply troubled! The Lord has concealed the thing from me, and hasn’t informed me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she asked, “Did I ask my lord for a son? Didn’t I beg you, ‘Don’t mislead me?’”
speaker: Narrator

text: At this he told Gehazi, “Get ready to run! Take my staff in your hand, and get on the road. Don’t greet anyone you meet. If anyone greets you, don’t respond. Just go lay my staff on the youngster’s face.”
speaker: Narrator

text: At this, the youngster’s mother replied, “As long as you and the Lord live, I’m not leaving you!” So he got up and followed her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Gehazi went on ahead of them and placed the staff on the youngster’s face, but when there was no sound or reaction, he returned, met Elisha, and told him, “The youngster has shown no sign of awakening.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Elisha entered the house, there was the youngster, dead and laid out on Elisha’s bed!
speaker: Narrator

text: So he entered, shut the door behind them both, and prayed to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he approached the child and lay down with his mouth near the child’s, with his eyes near those of the child, and taking the child’s hands in his. As Elisha stretched himself on the child, the child’s flesh began to grow warm.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he went downstairs, walked around back and forth inside the house once, went back up to his upper chamber, and stretched himself over the child again. The young man sneezed seven times and then opened his eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: He called out to Gehazi, “Go get the Shunammite woman!” So he called her. When she came in to see Elisha, he told her, “Take back your son!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she approached him, fell at his feet, bowing low to the ground, took back her son, and went out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha returned to Gilgal during a time of famine in the land. While the Guild of Prophets were having a meal with him, he instructed his attendant, “Put a large pot on the fire and boil some stew for the Guild of Prophets.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Somebody went out into the fields to grab some herbs, found a wild vine, and gathered a lap full of wild gourds, which he came and sliced up into the stew pot, but nobody else knew.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they served the men, they began to eat the stew. But they cried out, “That pot of stew is deadly, you man of God!” So they couldn’t eat the stew.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he replied, “Bring me some flour.” He tossed it into the pot and said, “Serve the people so they can eat.” Then there was nothing harmful in the pot.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later on, a man arrived from Baal-shalishah, bringing the man of God some bread as a first fruit offering. He had 20 loaves of barley and ripe ears of corn in his sack. So Elisha said, “Give them to the people so they can eat.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Elisha’s attendant asked, “What? Will this serve 100 men?”
But he replied, “Distribute it to the people so they can eat, because this is what the Lord says: ‘They will eat and have a surplus!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he served them, and they ate and had some left over, just as the Lord had indicated.
speaker: Narrator

text: Naaman, the commander of the army of the king of Aram, was a great man in the opinion of his master. He was highly favored, because by him the Lord had given victory to Aram. Though he was a mighty and valiant man, he was suffering from leprosy.
speaker: Narrator

text: On one of their raids to the territory of Israel, Aram had taken captive a young girl when she was an infant, who had eventually become an attendant to Naaman’s wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: She mentioned to her mistress, “If only my master were to visit the prophet who is in Samaria! He would cure him of his leprosy.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, Naaman went to inform his master and told him something like this: “Thus and so spoke the young woman from the territory of Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Aram replied, “Go now, and I’ll send a letter to the king of Israel.” So he left and took with him ten talents of silver and 6,000 units of gold, along with ten sets of clothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also brought the letter to the king of Israel, which read as follows: “…and now as this letter finds its way to you, look! I’ve sent my servant Naaman to you so you may heal him of his leprosy.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the king of Israel read the letter, he ripped his clothes and cried out, “Am I God? Can I kill and give life? Is this man sending me a request to heal a man’s leprosy? Let’s think about this—he’s looking for a reason to start a fight with me!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Elisha the man of God heard that the king of Israel had torn his clothes, he sent a message to the king and asked, “Why did you tear your clothes? Please, let the man come visit me and he will learn that there is a prophet in Israel!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Naaman arrived with his horses and chariots and stood in front of the door to Elisha’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha sent a messenger out to him, who told him, “Go bathe in the Jordan River seven times. Your flesh will be restored for you. Now stay clean!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Naaman flew into a rage and left, telling himself, “Look! I thought ‘He’s surely going to come out to me, stand still, call out in the name of the Lord his God, wave his hand over the infection, and cure the leprosy!’
speaker: Narrator

text: Aren’t the Abana and Pharpar rivers in Damascus better than all of the water in Israel? Couldn’t I just bathe in them and become clean?” So he turned away and left, filled with anger.
speaker: Narrator

text: But then his servants approached him and spoke with him. They said, “My father, had the prophet only asked of you something great, you would have done it, wouldn’t you? Yet he told you, ‘Bathe, and be clean…!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he went down and plunged himself into the Jordan River seven times, just as the man of God had said, and his flesh rejuvenated like the flesh of a newborn child. And he was clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Naaman went back to the man of God, along with his entire entourage, and stood before him. “Please look!” he said. “I know that there is no God in all the earth, except in Israel! So please, take a present from your servant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Elisha replied, “As the Lord lives, before whom I stand, I will not receive anything from you.” Though Naaman urged him to take it, Elisha declined.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Naaman asked, “No? Then please let your servant load two mules with dirt from Israel, because your servant will no longer offer any burnt offering or sacrifice to any other god but the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: In this one area may the Lord pardon your servant: Whenever my master enters the temple of Rimmon to worship there, he will lean on my hand while I bow down in the temple of Rimmon. So may the Lord pardon your servant in this one area.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Go in peace,” he said. So Naaman left.
After Naaman had gone only a short distance,
speaker: Narrator

text: Gehazi, the attendant to Elisha, the man of God, told himself, “Look how my master has spared this Aramean, Naaman! He declined to take from him what he brought. As the Lord lives, I’m going to run after him and get something from him.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Gehazi ran after Naaman.
When Naaman noticed someone running after him, he came down from his chariot, greeted him and asked, “Is everything all right?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Gehazi said, “Everything’s all right. My master sent me to tell you, ‘Just now two men from the Guild of Prophets have arrived from the hill country of Ephraim. Please give them each a talent of silver bullion and two sets of clothes.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Naaman said, “Please accept my invitation to take two talents of silver.” He urged him, binding two talents of silver in two bags, along with two sets of clothes. He placed them in the care of two of his young men, and they went on ahead of Gehazi.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he arrived at the stronghold, Gehazi took the bags from their custody and hid them away in the house. Then he sent the men away and they left.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Later he went to address his master. Elisha asked him, “Where did you go, Gehazi?”
“Your servant went nowhere in particular,” he said.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Elisha responded, “Didn’t my heart break as the man was turning from his chariot to greet you? Is now the time to receive money? To receive clothes? And olive groves, vineyards, sheep, oxen, servants, or female attendants?
speaker: Narrator

text: Naaman’s leprosy will plague you and your descendants forever!” As he left Elisha’s presence, he was infected with leprosy that looked like white snow.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day the Guild of Prophets told Elisha, “Notice how the place where we are living is too small for us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let’s go to the Jordan River, fashion some rafters, and build a place for us so we can live there.”
So he said, “Go!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Someone asked, “Would you be willing to come with your servants?”
“I’m willing,” he replied.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he accompanied them, and when they came to the Jordan River, they cut down some trees.
speaker: Narrator

text: It happened that as one of them was felling a beam, his axe head fell into the water. He cried out, “Oh no! Master! The axe was on loan to me!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The man of God asked, “Where did it fall?” When he was shown the place, he cut off a branch, tossed it there, and made the iron axe head float.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elisha said, “Pick it up!” So the young man reached out and picked it up.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eventually the king of Aram went to war against Israel, taking counsel with his advisors and concluding, “In such and such a place I’ll build my encampment.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the man of God sent a message to the king of Israel, warning him, “Keep an eye on that area, because the Arameans are going to be there!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel confirmed the matter about which the man of God had warned him. Having been forewarned, he was able to protect himself there on more than one or two occasions.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Aram flew into a rage over this, so he called in his advisors and asked them, “Will you please tell me which of us has joined the king of Israel?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “No, your majesty,” one of his servants said. “Elisha the prophet, who lives in Israel, tells the king of Israel what you talk about in your bedroom!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So the king ordered, “Go and discover where he is, so I may send men to take him into custody.”
Later somebody told him, “Look! He’s in Dothan!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king of Aram sent out horses, chariots, and an elite force, and they arrived during the night and surrounded the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, the attendant to the man of God got up early in the morning and went outside, and there were the elite forces, surrounding the city, accompanied by horses and chariots! So Elisha’s attendant cried out to him, “Oh no! Master! What will we do!?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha replied, “Stop being afraid, because there are more with us than with them!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elisha prayed, asking the Lord, “Please make him able to really see!” And so when the Lord enabled the young man to see, he looked, and there was the mountain, filled with horses and fiery chariots surrounding Elisha!
speaker: Narrator

text: When the army approached him, Elisha spoke to the Lord, asking him, “Lord, I’m asking you please to afflict this group of people with blindness!” So he afflicted them with blindness, just as Elisha had asked.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elisha told the army, “This isn’t the way, and this isn’t the city! Follow me, and I’ll bring you to the man you’re seeking.” Then he led them to Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they arrived in Samaria, Elisha asked the Lord, “Enable them to see again.” So the Lord did so, and there they were—right in the middle of Samaria!
speaker: Narrator

text: When the king of Israel saw Elisha, he asked him, “Shall I execute them, my father?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he replied, “No! You’re not to kill them! Would you execute those whom you’ve taken captive at the point of a sword or with your bow? Give them food and water so they can eat and drink. Then send them back to their master!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he prepared a large festival for them, and when they had finished eating and drinking, he sent them back to their master, and marauding gangs of Arameans never came into the territory of Israel again.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some time later, King Ben-hadad from Aram mustered his army, invaded the land, and attacked Samaria
speaker: Narrator

text: until there was a great famine throughout Samaria. The siege lasted until a donkey’s head cost 80 silver coins and one quarter of a unit of dove’s dung cost five silver coins.
speaker: Narrator

text: While the king of Israel was walking along the city wall, a woman cried out to him. “Help me, your majesty!” she said.
speaker: Narrator

text: He replied, “No! Since the Lord won’t give you victory, how will I be able to deliver you? From the threshing floor? From the wine press?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the king asked her, “What’s bothering you?”
She said, “This woman told me, ‘Give up your son, and we’ll eat him today, and we’ll eat my son tomorrow.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So we boiled my son and ate him. The next day, I told her, ‘Give me your son so we can eat him!’ But she has hidden her son!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the king heard what the woman said, he ripped his garments as he continued walking along the city wall. As the people watched, all of a sudden they noticed he was wearing sackcloth underneath his clothes, inside next to his flesh!
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “May God do to me—and more also!—if the head of Shaphat’s son Elisha remains on his shoulders today!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Elisha was sitting in his house, along with the elders, when the king sent a man to kill him, but before the messenger arrived, Elisha told the elders, “Are you watching how this descendant of murderers has ordered my head be cut off? Look, when the messenger arrives, shut the door and hold it to shut them out! Don’t you hear the sound of his master’s feet right behind him?”
speaker: Narrator

text: While he was still talking with them, the messenger arrived to see him and delivered the king’s message to Elisha, “Look! This evil has come from the Lord! Why should I wait for the Lord anymore?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Elisha responded, “Listen to this message from the Lord! ‘This is what the Lord says: “At about this time tomorrow, in Samaria’s city gate, a seah of finely ground flour will sell for a shekel, and two seahs of barley for a shekel.”’”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the royal attendant on whom the king depended responded to the man of God: “Look here! Even if the Lord were to open a window in the sky, how could this happen?”
He replied, “No, you look! You’ll see it with your eyes, but you won’t eat any of it!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there happened to be four lepers who were at that very moment at the entrance to the city gate. As they were talking with one another, they said, “Why are we sitting here waiting to die?
speaker: Narrator

text: If we tell ourselves, ‘Let’s remain in the city,’ we’ll die there since there’s famine in the city. But if we sit here, we’ll die, too. So let’s go over to the Arameans! If they spare our lives, we’ll live, and if they kill us…we’re dying anyway!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they got up at dusk and went out to the Aramean encampment. But when they arrived at the outskirts of the Aramean encampment, there was no one there!
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord had made the Aramean army hear the sounds of chariots, horses, and a large army, so they told one another, “Look! The king of Israel has hired the kings of the Hittites and the Egyptians to come attack us!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Arameans got up and ran away in the gathering darkness. They left behind their tents, horses, and donkeys just as they were—and fled for their lives!
speaker: Narrator

text: When the lepers arrived at the outskirts of the encampment, they entered one tent and ate and drank. Then they carried off from there some silver, gold, and clothes, and went out and hid them. After this, they returned, entered another tent, raided it, and went and hid all of that, too!
speaker: Narrator

text: But then they told each other, “We’re not doing the right thing. This is a day of good news, but if we keep quiet until morning, we’re sure to be punished! So let’s leave and go tell the king’s household!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they left, called out to the city gatekeepers, and reported to them: “We went out to the Aramean encampment, and there was nobody there! Not even the sound of men—only horses and donkeys tied up, and tents left just as they were!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The gatekeepers announced the report to the king’s attendants,
speaker: Narrator

text: so the king got up in the middle of the night and ordered his servants: “Let me explain what the Arameans have done to us. They know that we’re hungry, so they’ve left their encampment to conceal themselves in the surrounding fields. They’re telling themselves, ‘When they come out of the city, we’ll capture them alive and enter the city!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: One of his attendants suggested, “Please, let’s take five of the remaining horses, since those who remain here will end up like the rest of Israel, which has already died, and we’ll send them out to look.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they took two chariots and horses, and the king sent them out after the Aramean army with the orders, “Go and look!”
speaker: Narrator

text: They went out in the direction of the Jordan River, and the entire roadway was strewn with clothes and equipment that the Arameans had abandoned in their haste to leave! So the messengers returned and reported to the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: At this, the people went out and plundered the camp of the Arameans. At that time, a seah of finely ground flour was sold for a shekel, and two seahs of barley for a shekel, in accordance with the Lord’s message.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, the king appointed the same royal attendant on whom he depended to take control of the city gate, but the people trampled him to death in the gate, just as the man of God had told the king when the king came down to him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It happened just as the man of God had spoken to the king:
“At about this time tomorrow, in Samaria’s city gate, a seah of finely ground flour will sell for a shekel, and two seahs of barley for a shekel.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the royal attendant on whom the king depended responded to the man of God: “Look here! Even if the Lord were to make a window in the sky, how could this happen?”
He replied, “No, you look! You’ll see it with your eyes, but you won’t eat any of it!”
speaker: Narrator

text: And so it happened to him, because the people trampled him in the city gate and he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Elisha urged the woman whose son he had restored to life, “You must get up and leave with your household to go live wherever you can, because the Lord has called for a famine, and it’s going to come over the land for seven years.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the woman followed the instructions given to her by the man of God, and she went to the territory of the Philistines to live for seven years with her household.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the end of the seven years, the woman returned from the territory of the Philistines and went to the king in order to file an appeal regarding her house and her grain field.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king was talking with Gehazi, the attendant of the man of God. He had asked Gehazi, “Please tell me about all of the great things that Elisha has done.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Just as he was telling the king about Elisha’s having restored the dead to life, the woman whose son had been restored arrived and appealed to the king for her house and her land!
Gehazi told the king, “Your majesty, this is the woman! And here’s her son, whom Elisha restored to life!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king consulted with the woman, who related the story. So the king appointed a court official to represent her and ordered him: “Restore to her everything that belonged to her, including all of the produce that her fields yielded from the day she left the land until now.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Later on, Elisha traveled to Damascus. King Ben-hadad of Aram was ill, but someone informed him, “The man of God has come here!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king told Hazael, “Take a gift with you and go meet the man of God. Inquire of the Lord through him and ask, ‘Will I recover from this sickness?’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Hazael went out to meet with him and took a gift with him—40 camel loads filled with samples of everything good in Damascus. He approached the man of God and said, “Your son King Ben-hadad from Aram has sent me to you to ask you, ‘Will I recover from this sickness?’”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Elisha told him, “Go tell him, ‘You will certainly recover,’ but the Lord has shown me that he will certainly die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elisha looked steadily at Hazael until Hazael grew ashamed, and then the man of God began to cry.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Why are you crying, sir?” Hazael asked.
“Because I know the evil that you’re about to bring on the Israelis,” he replied. “You’ll burn down their fortified cities, execute their young men with swords, dash to pieces their little ones, and you’ll tear open their pregnant women!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But Hazael responded, “What? Who am I, your servant, that I should do such a horrible thing?”
But Elisha answered, “The Lord has shown me that you will be king over Aram.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So he left Elisha and returned to his master, who asked him, “What did Elisha tell you?”
He replied, “He told me that you would certainly get better.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the very next day, Hazael grabbed a thick covering, soaked it in water, and spread it over the king’s face, and he suffocated. Then Hazael succeeded Ben-hadad as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sometime during the fifth year of the reign of Ahab’s son Joram, king of Israel (while Jehoshaphat was still ruling as king of Judah), Jehoshaphat’s son Jehoram ascended to the throne of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was 32 years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem for eight years.
speaker: Narrator

text: He lived his life like the kings of Israel did, following the example of Ahab’s household when he married Ahab’s daughter and practiced what was evil in the Lord’s presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord remained unwilling to destroy Judah for the sake of his servant David, since he had promised to keep David’s lamp burning brightly through his descendants every day.
speaker: Narrator

text: During Jehoram’s lifetime, Edom rebelled from Judah’s hegemony and appointed a king to rule over themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joram crossed over to Zair, along with all of his chariots. At night he attacked the Edomites who had surrounded him and the commanders of his chariots, but the army ran away to their tents.
speaker: Narrator

text: Edom remains in rebellion against Judah to this day, and Libnah revolted at the same time.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the official acts of Joram, along with everything else that he did, are recorded in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah, are they not?
speaker: Narrator

text: After Jehoram was laid to rest with his ancestors in the City of David, his son Ahaziah replaced him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoram’s son Ahaziah began to reign as king of Judah during the twelfth year of the reign of Ahab’s son Joram, king of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ahaziah was 22 years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem for one year.
His mother was named Athaliah. She was the granddaughter of Omri, king of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahaziah lived his life following the example of Ahab’s household, practicing what the Lord considered to be evil, just like the household of Ahab, because he was a son-in-law to Ahab’s household.
speaker: Narrator

text: He joined Ahab’s son Joram in an attack on King Hazael of Aram at Ramoth-gilead, and that’s where the Arameans wounded Joram.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King Joram retreated to Jezreel to recover from the wounds that the Arameans had inflicted on him at Ramah during the battle against King Hazael of Aram. Jehoram’s son Ahaziah, king of Judah, went to visit Ahab’s son Joram in Jezreel because Joram was sick.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha called one of the members of the Guild of Prophets and told him, “Get ready to run, take this flask of oil in your hand, and go to Ramoth-gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as you get there, go find Jehoshaphat’s son Jehu, the grandson of Nimshi. When you do, go in, tell him to get up and go apart with you away from his brothers. Lead him into a private chamber,
speaker: Narrator

text: take the flask of oil, and pour it out on his head. Then tell him, ‘This is what the Lord says: I’m anointing you king over Israel.’ Then open the door and leave. Don’t linger there!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the young man, who was an attendant to the prophet, went to Ramoth-gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When he arrived, the army commanders were seated, so he said, “I have a message for you, captain!”
Jehu asked, “For which one of us?”
“For you, captain!” he answered.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jehu got up and went inside the house, and the young man told him, “This is what the Lord, the God of Israel says: ‘I have anointed you king over the people of the Lord—that is, over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to attack the household of your master Ahab, so I may avenge the blood of my servants the prophets, as well as the blood of all of the servants of the Lord that has been spilled at Jezebel’s orders.
speaker: Narrator

text: The entire household of Ahab will die, and I will cut off from Ahab every male person in Israel, whether imprisoned or surviving.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make the household of Ahab like the household of Nebat’s son Jeroboam and the household of Ahijah’s son Baasha.
speaker: Narrator

text: Furthermore, the dogs will eat Jezebel in the territory of Jezreel. There will be no burial for her.’” Then he opened the door and left.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As Jehu was coming out to his master’s attendants, one of them asked him, “Is everything all right? Why did this maniac visit you?”
“You know the man and how he speculates,” Jehu replied.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“That’s a lie!” they said. “Tell us what’s going on!”
“He said ‘This and that’ to me,” he responded. “‘This is what the Lord says: “I have anointed you king over Israel.”’”
speaker: Narrator

text: At this, each man quickly grabbed his own garment, placed it under him at the top of the stairs, sounded a trumpet, and announced, “Jehu is king!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Jehoshaphat’s son Jehu, the grandson of Nimshi, had been conspiring against Joram while Joram and all the army of Israel had been defending Ramoth-gilead against King Hazael from Aram. (
speaker: Narrator

text: But King Joram had returned to Jezreel to recover from wounds he had sustained from the Arameans when he had fought against King Hazael from Aram.) So Jehu concluded, “Since this is what you’ve decided, then let no one get away, leave the city, and go report to Jezreel!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehu rode by chariot to Jezreel, since Joram was recovering there. King Ahaziah from Judah had come to visit Joram.
speaker: Narrator

text:
While the watchman was standing guard in the tower at Jezreel, he watched Jehu’s entourage arrive. So he called out, “I see a group arriving.”
Joram ordered, “Take a horseman, send him out to meet them, and have him ask, ‘Have you come in peace?’”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So a horseman went out, greeted Jehu and said, “This is what the king said: ‘Have you come in peace?’”
But Jehu responded, “What do you have to do with peace? Fall in behind me.”
The watchman reported, “The messenger arrived there, but he hasn’t returned.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Joram sent out a second horseman, who went out to them and said, “This is what the king said: ‘Have you come in peace?’”
Jehu responded, “What do you have to do with peace? Fall in behind me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The watchman reported to Joram, “He arrived there, but he hasn’t returned. Also, he drives like Nimshi’s son Jehu drives—irrationally!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joram replied, “Let’s begin our attack!” As soon as his chariot was prepared, both King Joram of Israel and King Ahaziah of Judah went out, each in his own chariot, to fight against Jehu. They met together in the property that had belonged to Naboth the Jezreelite.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As soon as Joram noticed Jehu, he cried out, “Peace, Jehu?”
Jehu replied, “What peace, given your mother Jezebel’s prostitution and all of her witchcraft?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joram reined his horse around to flee and cried out to Ahaziah, “Ahaziah! Treachery!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jehu drew his bow with all of his strength, shooting Joram between his shoulder blades. The arrow pierced his heart, and he collapsed in his chariot.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, Jehu called out to Bidkar, his third in command, “Pick up Joram’s body and throw it in the field, the property that belonged to Naboth the Jezreelite, because you and I remember how when we were riding together in pursuit of his father Ahab, that the Lord pronounced this oracle against him:
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘This is what the Lord says, “I have certainly observed the blood of Naboth and his sons, and I will repay you on this property,” declares the Lord.’
“Therefore take the body and throw it in the field, just as the Lord said.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
As soon as King Ahaziah of Judah observed this, he attempted to flee by the garden house road, but Jehu pursued him. At the ascent toward Gur which is near Ibleam, he ordered, “Shoot him in the chariot, too!”
Ahaziah fled to Megiddo, where he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahaziah’s servants transported the king’s body by chariot to Jerusalem and buried it in his own sepulcher near his ancestors in the City of David.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahaziah had begun to reign over Judah in the eleventh year of the reign of Ahab’s son Joram.
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as Jehu arrived at Jezreel, Jezebel adorned her eyes, arranged her hair, and peered out a window.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jehu had entered through the gate, she asked, “Was Zimri, who murdered his master, received well?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehu looked up toward the window and called out, “Who is on my side? Who?” When two or three eunuchs looked out at him,
speaker: Narrator

text:
he ordered, “Throw her down!”
So they did, and her blood splashed against the wall and on the horses, while Jehu trampled her underfoot.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later on, after he had come in to eat and drink, he ordered, “Go and see to this cursed woman, and bury her, because she was a king’s daughter.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But when they went out to bury her, they found nothing left of her except her skull, her feet, and the palms of her hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So they returned and reported to Jehu, and he responded, “This fulfills this message from the Lord that he spoke through his servant Elijah the foreigner, who said:
‘Dogs will eat Jezebel’s flesh on the property of Jezreel,
speaker: Narrator

text: and her corpse will lie like dung on the surface of the field on the property in Jezreel, but no one will say, “This is Jezebel.”’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Ahab had 70 sons who lived in Samaria. So Jehu wrote letters and sent them to Samaria—to the rulers of Jezreel, the elders, and the guardians of Ahab’s children. He told them,
speaker: Narrator

text: “As soon as you receive this letter (since your master’s children are with you, you have chariots and horses there with you, and you are protected by a walled city and weaponry),
speaker: Narrator

text: select the best and most qualified of your master’s sons, set him in place on his father’s throne, and fight for your master’s dynasty!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But they were too terrified, and so they told one another, “Look! Two previous kings couldn’t stand up to Jehu, so how can we?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the household overseer and the city supervisor, along with the elders and the children’s guardians, sent word to Jehu, telling him, “We will serve you and do everything you ask. We won’t set up a king, so do what you want to do.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But Jehu wrote them another letter: “If you’re loyal to me, and if you intend to obey my commands, then bring the heads of your master’s sons and meet me in Jezreel about this time tomorrow.”
Now the king’s sons, totaling 70 men, were living with the leading men of the city, who were their guardians.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the letter from Jehu arrived, the city leaders arrested the king’s sons, slaughtered all 70 of them, put their heads in baskets, and sent them to Jehu at Jezreel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the messenger arrived to report to the king, he said, “They have brought the heads of the king’s sons.”
Jehu replied, “Put them in two piles at the entrance of the city gate until morning.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The next morning, Jehu went out, stood still, and announced to all the people: “Are you righteous? I conspired against my master and killed him, but who slaughtered all of these?
speaker: Narrator

text: Keep this in mind—not a single statement by the Lord will fail to come about that he spoke concerning Ahab’s dynasty, because the Lord has accomplished what he predicted by his servant Elijah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jehu executed all those who remained from Ahab’s dynasty in Jezreel, including all of Ahab’s men, his friends, and his priests, until there remained not even one survivor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehu got up, left the city, and went to Samaria. When he arrived at the shearing house that was located on the way,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jehu met up with the relatives of King Ahaziah of Judah. He asked them, “Who are you?”
They answered, “We’re Ahaziah’s relatives, and we’ve come down to greet the king’s sons and the sons of the queen mother.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehu ordered, “Take them alive!” So Jehu’s soldiers captured them and executed all 42 of them near the pit at the shearing house. He left none of them alive.
speaker: Narrator

text:
After he left there, he encountered Rechab’s son Jehonadab. After he greeted him, Jehu asked him, “Is your heart right, as my heart is with yours?”
“It is,” Jehonadab answered.
“If it is,” Jehu replied, “Put out your hand.” So Jehonadab stuck out his hand, and Jehu took him up to stand in his chariot.
speaker: Narrator

text: He told him, “Come with me and see my enthusiasm for the Lord!” So Jehu had Jehonadab ride in his chariot.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jehu arrived in Samaria, he executed everyone who remained of Ahab’s household in Samaria, until he had utterly destroyed Ahab in accordance with the message from the Lord that he spoke to Elijah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehu assembled all the people and announced to them, “Ahab served Baal a little, but Jehu will serve him a lot!
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore summon all of Baal’s prophets to me, including all his worshipers and all his priests. Don’t leave even one out, because I’ve prepared a great sacrifice for Baal. Whoever doesn’t show up doesn’t live!” But Jehu did this deceptively, intending to destroy Baal’s worshippers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jehu ordered, “Set aside a solemn assembly for Baal!”
And so they proclaimed it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehu sent the proclamation throughout Israel, and all the Baal worshipers came. There wasn’t a single man left who failed to come. When they entered Baal’s temple, it was filled from one end to the other.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehu ordered the one in charge of the wardrobe, “Bring out garments for all of the worshipers of Baal.” So he brought out garments for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehu and Rechab’s son Jehonadab entered Baal’s temple, and Jehu told the Baal worshipers, “Look around and be sure that no servant of the Lord is here among you, but only worshipers of Baal.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they went in to offer sacrifices and burnt offerings. Meanwhile, Jehu had stationed 80 men outside, ordering them, “If any of these men whom I’ve brought into your control escape, the one who allows it will forfeit his life.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as he had completed the burnt offering, Jehu ordered the guards and the officers, “Go in and execute them. Don’t let even one man escape.” So they executed them with swords, and the guards and the officers threw the bodies out and proceeded into the inner room of Baal’s temple,
speaker: Narrator

text: from which they brought out the sacred pillars and burned them.
speaker: Narrator

text: They also cut down the pillar to Baal, tore apart Baal’s temple, and turned it into a latrine—and it remains that way today.
speaker: Narrator

text: That’s how Jehu eradicated Baal from Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even so, Jehu never abandoned the sins of Nebat’s son Jeroboam, who caused Israel to sin, regarding the golden calves that were at Bethel and Dan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, the Lord told Jehu, “Because you have done well in carrying out what I saw as the right thing to do by completing everything I had in mind regarding Ahab’s dynasty, your sons will sit on the throne of Israel to the fourth generation.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jehu did not remain careful to walk in the instruction of the Lord God of Israel with all his heart. He never abandoned the sins of Jeroboam that had caused Israel to sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: In those days, the Lord began to reduce Israel in size: Hazael defeated them throughout the territory of Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text: from the Jordan River eastward, all the territory of Gilead, the descendants of Gad, the descendants of Reuben, and the descendants of Manasseh, from Aroer by the Valley of the Arnon, including Gilead and Bashan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now as to the rest of Jehu’s activities, including his valiant deeds, they are recorded in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel, are they not?
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehu died, as did his ancestors, and they buried him in Samaria. His son Jehoahaz reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehu reigned over Israel in Samaria for 28 years.
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as Ahaziah’s mother Athaliah learned that her son had died, she seized the throne and executed the entire royal bloodline.
speaker: Narrator

text: But King Joram’s daughter Jehosheba, who was Ahaziah’s sister, rescued Ahaziah’s son Joash from the group of the king’s sons who were being executed and hid him and his nurse in her bedroom, concealing him from Athaliah so he was not put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joash remained hidden with her in the Lord’s Temple for six years while Athaliah reigned over the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: But during the seventh year of her reign, Jehoiada went out and called together the rulers of hundreds, the captains, and the guards, and assembled them together inside the Lord’s Temple. He made a covenant with them, making them take an oath in the Lord’s Temple, and then he revealed the king’s son to them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He ordered them:
“Here’s what we’ll do: A third of you will enter here on this coming Sabbath dressed as guardians of the watch for the king’s palace,
speaker: Narrator

text: with a third of you at the Sur gate, and a third at the gate behind the guards. Keep watch over the palace and defend it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Two of you who enter here on this coming Sabbath are to stand watch at the Lord’s Temple,
speaker: Narrator

text: guarding the king and surrounding him with weapons in hand. Whoever comes within range is to be killed. Stay with the king wherever he goes, coming or going.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the captains of hundreds did just as Jehoiada the priest ordered. Each one of them assembled his men who were to enter on the Sabbath, along with those who were to leave on the Sabbath, and approached Jehoiada the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priest issued King David’s personal spears and shields that had been stored in the Lord’s Temple to the captains of hundreds.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the guards stood assembled, every soldier with weapons in hand, surrounding the king from the right side corner of the Temple to the left side corner, including around the altar and the Temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he brought out the king’s son, put the royal crown on him, presented him with the Testimony, and installed him as king. They anointed him, applauded, and said, “May the king live!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Athaliah heard all of the commotion coming from those who were guarding the people, she approached the people who were in the Lord’s Temple.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She looked around—and there was the king, standing near a column, as was the royal custom! He was accompanied by the commanding officers, along with trumpeters who stood beside the king. All the people of the land sounded trumpets in their excitement.
But Athaliah tore her clothes and bellowed, “It’s a plot! A conspiracy!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoiada the priest commanded the captains in charge of the army, “Take her out the back way and execute anybody who follows her,” since the priest had also issued this order: “Let’s not put her to death in the Lord’s Temple.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they arrested Athaliah, took her out through the same entrance used by the horses for entering the king’s palace, and executed her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jehoiada entered into a covenant with the Lord, the king, and the people, that they would live as the Lord’s people, and also entered into a covenant with the king and the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all of the people of the land entered Baal’s temple, tore it down, and broke his altars and his images to pieces, killing Mattan the priest of Baal right in front of the altars. Furthermore, Jehoiada the priest appointed officers to guard the Lord’s Temple,
speaker: Narrator

text: and brought the commanders of hundreds, the Carites, the guards, and all the people of the land, taking the king out of the Lord’s Temple, marching through the guard’s gate to the king’s palace, where Joash took his seat on the throne of the kings.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, everyone throughout the land rejoiced and the city was at peace, because they had executed Athaliah at the king’s palace.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoash began to reign as king when he was seven years old,
speaker: Narrator

text: ascending to the throne in the seventh year of the reign of Jehu and then reigning for 40 years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Zibiah from Beer-sheba.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoash did what the Lord considered to be right during the entire time when Jehoiada the priest was instructing him,
speaker: Narrator

text: except that the high places were not demolished, so the people continued to sacrifice and burn incense on the high places.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoash spoke to the priests about all of the proceeds of the consecrated gifts that were being brought into the Lord’s Temple, cash from every man who was traveling through the area, cash obtained by personal assessment, and all the cash that came through voluntary gifts into the Lord’s Temple:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Let the priests get support for themselves from their own donors, and let them repair the Temple wherever a leak in need of repair is discovered.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But 23 years into the reign of King Jehoash, the priests still had not repaired the leaks in the Temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: So King Jehoash called for Jehoiada the priest, along with other priests, and asked them, “Why haven’t you fixed the leaks in the Temple? Stop receiving donations from your acquaintances for repairing the leaks in the Temple.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the priests agreed to receive no more cash from the people, but they didn’t repair the leaks in the Temple, either.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jehoiada the priest grabbed a chest, bored an opening in its lid, and placed it next to the altar, on the right side as one enters the Lord’s Temple. The priests who tended the entryway put all the money that was brought into the Lord’s Temple into the chest.
speaker: Narrator

text: As a result, whenever they noticed that there was a lot of money in the chest, the king’s secretary and the high priest went forward, put the money in bags, counted the money that had been given over to the Lord’s Temple,
speaker: Narrator

text: and disbursed the cash directly into the hands of those who did the work and who were in charge of the oversight of the Lord’s Temple. They paid it to the carpenters and builders who worked on the Lord’s Temple,
speaker: Narrator

text: to masons and stonecutters, and for procurement of timber and quarried stone for making repairs to the Lord’s Temple, and for all outlays needed for repairs of the Temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: But no provision was included for the Lord’s Temple from the money that was brought into the Lord’s Temple for silver basins, snuffers, bowls, trumpets, or any vessels made of gold or silver,
speaker: Narrator

text: because that money had been allocated to the workmen who were repairing the Lord’s Temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: Furthermore, they required no accounting from the men into whose hand they had paid the money to do the work, because the workers acted in good faith.
speaker: Narrator

text: The money from the guilt offerings and from the sin offerings was not brought into the Lord’s Temple, because it was allocated to the priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, King Hazael of Aram invaded and attacked Gath, captured it, and then set out to approach Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: So King Jehoash of Judah took all of the sacred things that his ancestors Jehoshaphat, Jehoram, and Ahaziah, kings of Judah, had dedicated, along with his own dedicated things, and all the gold that could be located within the treasure vaults of the Lord’s Temple and in the king’s palace, and paid off King Hazael of Aram. Then Hazael left Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the Joash’s activities—everything he did—are written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah, are they not?
speaker: Narrator

text: His servants rose up in rebellion, formed a conspiracy, and assassinated Joash in the palace at the terrace ramparts while he was on his way down to Silla.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shimeath’s son Jozacar and Shomer’s son Jehozabad, his servants, attacked him and he died. They buried him alongside his ancestors in the City of David, and his son Amaziah became king to replace him.
speaker: Narrator

text: During the twenty-third year of the reign of Ahaziah’s son Joash, king of Judah, Jehu’s son Jehoahaz began his seventeen year reign in Samaria over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did what the Lord considered to be evil, after the pattern of Nebat’s son Jeroboam. By doing so, he caused Israel to sin, and he never changed course from it.
speaker: Narrator

text: As a result, the Lord’s wrath flared up against Israel, so he handed them over to domination by King Hazael of Aram and later into constant domination by Hazael’s son Ben-hadad.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jehoahaz sought the Lord, and the Lord paid attention to him, because the Lord had been watching the oppression that Israel was enduring from the king of Aram.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord provided Israel with a deliverer, so they escaped the Aramean oppression while the descendants of Israel lived in tents as they had formerly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, they did not change course away from the sins of Jeroboam’s household, by which he caused Israel to sin, but continued on that same course, with Asherah poles remaining in place in Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Aramean king had left only 50 cavalry, ten chariots, and 10,000 soldiers out of the army belonging to Jehoahaz, because the king of Aram had destroyed the others, making them like chaff left over after threshing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of the activities of Jehoahaz, including everything he did and his grandeur, are recorded in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel, are they not?
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jehoahaz died, as did his ancestors, and he was buried in Samaria while his son Joash replaced him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: During the thirty-seventh year of the reign of King Joash of Judah, Jehoahaz’s son Jehoash began a sixteen year reign as king over Israel in Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: He practiced what the Lord considered to be evil, not changing course from all of the sins practiced by Nebat’s son Jeroboam by which he caused Israel to sin. Instead, he continued on that same course.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of Joash’s activities, including everything he did and the vehemence with which he fought against King Amaziah of Judah are recorded in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel, are they not?
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joash died, as did his ancestors, and Jeroboam assumed his throne after Joash was buried in Samaria with the kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Elisha fell ill with the sickness from which he was about to die, King Joash of Israel came down to see him, wept in his presence, and told him, “My father, Israel’s chariots and cavalry!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elisha told him, “Pick up a bow and some arrows.” So he picked up a bow and some arrows.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elisha told Israel’s king, “Draw the bow!” As he did so, Elisha laid his hands on top of the king’s hands
speaker: Narrator

text:
and ordered him, “Open a window that faces east.” So he did so.
Elisha ordered him, “Shoot!” So he shot.
Then Elisha said, “This is the Lord’s arrow of victory—the victory arrow against Aram, because you will defeat the Arameans at Aphek until you will have utterly finished them off.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
After this Elisha said, “Pick up the arrows.” So the king picked them up.
Then Elisha told the king of Israel, “Strike the ground!” So he struck it three times and then stood still.
speaker: Narrator

text: At this, the man of God became angry at him and told him, “You should have struck five or six times! Then you would have attacked Aram until you would have destroyed it! But as it is now, you’ll defeat Aram only three times!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, Elisha died and was buried. Now at that time, various Moabite marauders had been invading the land each spring.
speaker: Narrator

text: One day while some Israelis were burying a man, they saw some marauders, so they threw the man into Elisha’s grave. But when the man fell against Elisha’s remains, he revived and rose to his feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, King Hazael of Aram had been oppressing Israel throughout the reign of Jehoahaz,
speaker: Narrator

text: but the Lord showed grace to them, displayed his compassion toward them, and turned to them due to his covenant with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. He would not destroy them or evict them from his presence up until that time.
speaker: Narrator

text: After King Hazael of Aram died, his son Ben-hadad replaced him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time, Jehoahaz’s son Jehoash recaptured from Hazael’s son Ben-hadad the cities that Hazael had captured through warfare from the control of Jehoahaz, Jehoash’s father. Joash defeated and recovered cities of Israel from Ben-hadad three times.
speaker: Narrator

text: Amaziah, son of Judah’s King Joash, became king during the second year of the reign of Joash, son of King Joahaz of Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text: at the age of 25. He reigned 29 years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Jehoaddin; she was from Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: He practiced what the Lord considered to be right, but not like his ancestor David did. He acted as his father Joash had done,
speaker: Narrator

text: except that the high places were not abolished. The people continued to offer sacrifices and to burn incense on the high places.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later on, as soon as he was in firm control of his kingdom, he executed the servants who had murdered his father the king,
speaker: Narrator

text: but he did not execute the children of the murderers, in keeping with what is written in the Book of the Law of Moses, as the Lord had commanded: “Fathers must not be put to death because of their children’s sin; nor are children to die because of their fathers’ sin, for each person is to be put to death for his own sin.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joash executed 10,000 Edomites in the Salt Valley and captured Sela in battle, renaming it Joktheel, which remains its name to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, Amaziah sent couriers to Jehoahaz’s son Jehoash, grandson of King Jehu of Israel, challenging him, “Come on! Let’s fight face to face!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But King Jehoash of Israel sent this message to King Amaziah of Judah: “The thorn bush in Lebanon sent this message to the cedar of Lebanon: ‘Give your daughter to my son in marriage.’ But just then a wild beast from Lebanon wandered by and trampled down the thorn bush.
speaker: Narrator

text: You just defeated Edom and you’re arrogant. Bask in your victory and stay home. Why incite trouble so that you—yes, you!—fall, along with Judah with you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Amaziah refused to listen. So Israel’s King Jehoash and Judah’s King Amaziah faced each other at Beth-shemesh, which is part of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah was defeated by Israel, and everybody fled to their own tents.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King Jehoash of Israel captured Judah’s King Amaziah, the son of Jehoash and grandson of Ahaziah, at Beth-shemesh. He went to Jerusalem and demolished 400 cubits of the wall of Jerusalem from the Ephraim Gate to the Corner Gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: He confiscated all the gold and silver, all the instruments he could find in the Lord’s Temple and in the palace treasuries. He also captured some hostages and then returned to Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of Jehoash’s activities that he undertook, including his valor in fighting King Amaziah of Judah, are recorded in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel, are they not?
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoash died, as had his ancestors, and he was buried in Samaria alongside the kings of Israel. His son Jeroboam reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joash’s son, King Amaziah of Judah, lived for fifteen years after Jehoahaz’ son, King Jehoash of Israel, died.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of Amaziah’s activities are recorded in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah, are they not?
speaker: Narrator

text: A conspiracy arose against him in Jerusalem, and he ran off to Lachish, but he was pursued to Lachish and killed there.
speaker: Narrator

text: His body was brought back on horses and he was buried at Jerusalem alongside his ancestors in the City of David.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people of Judah took Azariah, who was sixteen years old, and installed him as king to take the place of his father Amaziah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He rebuilt Elath and restored it to Judah. Later on the king died, as did his ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the fifteenth year of the reign of Amaziah son of Joash, king of Judah, Jeroboam son of Joash, king of Israel, began a 41 year reign in Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did what the Lord considered to be evil by not abandoning all the sins of Nebat’s son Jeroboam, who made Israel sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: He rebuilt Israel’s coastline from the entrance of Hamath as far as the Sea of the Arabah, in accordance with the message from the Lord God of Israel that he spoke through his servant Jonah the prophet, Amittai’s son, who was from Gath-hepher.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord observed Israel’s bitter misery, and there was no one left, neither slave nor free, and there was no deliverer for Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord had never said that he would erase the name of Israel from under heaven. Instead, he delivered them by Joash’s son Jeroboam.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of Jeroboam’s actions—everything he did, including his powerful fighting and how on behalf of Israel he restored Damascus and Hamath to Judah—are recorded in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel, are they not?
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeroboam died, as had his ancestors the kings of Israel, and his son Zechariah became king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Amaziah’s son Azariah began reigning during the twenty-seventh year of the reign of Jeroboam, king of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was sixteen years old when he began to reign, and he reigned 52 years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Jecoliah; she was from Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did what the Lord considered to be right, just as his father Amaziah had done in everything,
speaker: Narrator

text: except that the high places were never removed, and the people kept on sacrificing and burning incense on the high places.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord struck the king so that he was afflicted with leprosy until the day he died. He lived in a separate house while his son Jotham managed the household and ruled the people who lived in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of Azariah’s activities, including everything he did, are recorded in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah, are they not?
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, Azariah died, as had his ancestors, and they buried him with his ancestors in the City of David. His son Jotham then reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: During the thirty-eighth year of the reign of Azariah, king of Judah, Jeroboam’s son Zachariah began a six-month reign in Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: He did what the Lord considered to be evil, just as his ancestors had done. He never abandoned the sins of Nebat’s son Jeroboam, who caused Israel to sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jabesh’s son Shallum conspired against him and attacked him in full view of the people, killed him, and reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of Zachariah’s activities are recorded in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what the Lord told Jehu: “Your children will sit on Israel’s throne for the next four generations.” And that is what happened:
speaker: Narrator

text: Jabesh’s son Shallum began his reign in the thirty-ninth year of the reign of Uzziah, king of Judah. He reigned a full month in Samaria,
speaker: Narrator

text: then Gadi’s son Menahem approached Samaria from Tirzah and attacked Jabesh’s son Shallum, executed him, and reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of Shallum’s activities, including the conspiracy that he carried out, are recorded in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel, are they not?
speaker: Narrator

text: At another time, Menahem attacked Tiphsah and all of its inhabitants, including its coastlands from Tirzah, because they would not open the city gate for him. After defeating them, he ripped open all of their pregnant women.
speaker: Narrator
